text: What's up, outliers? Today, we're going to talk about making a backdoor Roth IRA contribution so that you could trade options in your IRA account. So let's talk first about why a Roth versus a traditional. Then we'll talk about why backdoor. And I'm going to give you literally a step-by-step process. I literally just completed mine for the year, so sharing with you for years. So the first thing, why a Roth? Well, a Roth allows for tax free growth of your capital, very similar to a traditional in that sense. However, as compared to traditional, where there's no tax on the contribution with a Roth, you tax on the contribution, but then you are not taxed on the withdrawal. This is useful if you think your income in the future is likely to be higher than it is now. And for a lot of traders that will be the case for people that are working in W2 jobs and stuff like that, probably less. So obviously, consult a tax professional, not a dude on the internet. Next step, why backdoor? Well, it's actually pretty simple. It's because if you fall into some of these various buckets, you literally cannot contribute to a Roth IRA. So for example, if you're single and you make over 161,000, you cannot contribute. If you're married, filed jointly, you cannot contribute. If it's over 240,000, which is kind of a bummer. Because again, for traders and people who invest, there's a good chance

This is some people do it out of a bit of concern trying to reduce their potential footprint for being flagged. But the reality is it's completely legal to do. And if you accrue any gains while you hold that position, then you run into the pro-radar rule. So once you have your traditional, you make your contribution that's non-deductible, then you once your funds settle, which typically takes a couple days by itself, we convert it to a Roth IRA. If there are no gains on the traditional, then there's no tax on the conversion. If there is or are gains existing or you accrue them in the meantime before you complete the conversion, then you do pay taxes on the gains, but there is no penalty to do so. So it's essentially just going to increase your tax footprint a little bit unnecessarily. Now, the last thing, we report the conversion on our taxes. And there's essentially two forms. There's the IRS form 8606, which is for non-deductible contributions. You literally can just type in IRS form 8606 and it will pop up. I want to put it into the Roth. I want to do a there's two different. There's full or complete and then a partial. So typically would be complete because you want to get everything out of the account and then move it into the Roth. So the whole point behind doing this is to be able to move money into your Roth IRA once you get priced out of being able to directly contribute. And this isn't specific for options trading. I do trade options in my IRA accounts. However, this is for anybody that's trying to get money into your Roth IRA. This process is about the same.
